title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others‚Äô private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@rstudio.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla‚Äôs code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to tidymodels
text: Typos grammatical errors documentation may edited directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. YES ‚úÖ: edit roxygen comment .R file R/ directory. üö´: edit .Rd file man/ directory. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation.

title: Contributing to tidymodels
text: submit üéØ pull request tidymodels package, always file issue confirm tidymodels team agrees idea happy basic proposal. pull requests, recommend create fork repo usethis::create_from_github(), initiate new branch usethis::pr_init(). Look build status making changes. README contains badges continuous integration services used package. New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don‚Äôt restyle code nothing PR. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md current development version header describing changes made followed GitHub username, links relevant issue(s)/PR(s). use testthat. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Using corrr with databases
text: simple SQLite database used example. temporary database created, mtcars data set copied . db_mtcars variable pointer new table inside database, hold data. Even though formal data.frame object, db_mtcars can use data.frame simply pipe correlate() function. correlate() function check type object passed, database-backed table, meaning tbl_sql() object class, use new tidyeval code calculate correlations inside database. function automatically retrieve results operation. tidyeval-based function ensures cor_df object returned, can used functions corrr package.

title: Using corrr with databases
text: connections using sparklyr, corrr use package function called ml_corr() run correlations time. done hood. user just needs pass tbl_spark object correlate() function, corrr automatically select right function run.

title: Using corrr with databases
text: using correlate() database-backed table, please make sure keep following items mind: pearson method supported. default method, necessary pass . different method chosen, operation return error. pairwise complete observations used. Meaning use argument set pairwise.complete.obs. y argument supported. means 1--1 comparisons needed, pre-select two variables prior passing correlate() function. diagonal argument accepts NA‚Äôs.

title: Using corrr
text: Using corrr starts correlate(), acts like base correlation function cor(). differs defaulting pairwise deletion, returning correlation data frame (cor_df) following structure: tbl additional class, cor_df extra ‚Äúterm‚Äù column Standardized variances (matrix diagonal) set missing values (NA) can ignored. work , let‚Äôs create correlation data frame using correlate() mtcars data comes R:

title: Using corrr
text: first, correlation data frame might seem like unnecessary complexity compared traditional matrix. However, purpose corrr help use explore correlations, mathematical statistical operations. Thus, correlations data frame, can make use packages help us work data frames like dplyr, tidyr, ggplot2, focus using data pipelines. Lets look examples: Furthermore, diagonal set missing, don‚Äôt need put extra effort ignore summarizing correlations. example:
code: library(dplyr)  # Filter rows to occasions in which cyl has a correlation of .7 or more with # another variable. d %>% filter(cyl > .7) #> # A tibble: 3 √ó 12 #>   term     mpg   cyl   disp     hp   drat     wt   qsec     vs     am #>   <chr>  <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 disp  -0.848 0.902 NA      0.791 -0.710  0.888 -0.434 -0.710 -0.591 #> 2 hp    -0.776 0.832  0.791 NA     -0.449  0.659 -0.708 -0.723 -0.243 #> 3 wt    -0.868 0.782  0.888  0.659 -0.712 NA     -0.175 -0.555 -0.692 #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: gear <dbl>, carb <dbl>  # Select the mpg, cyl and disp columns (and term) d %>% select(term, mpg, cyl, disp) #> # A tibble: 11 √ó 4 #>    term     mpg    cyl   disp #>    <chr>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 mpg   NA     -0.852 -0.848 #>  2 cyl   -0.852 NA      0.902 #>  3 disp  -0.848  0.902 NA     #>  4 hp    -0.776  0.832  0.791 #>  5 drat   0.681 -0.700 -0.710 #>  6 wt    -0.868  0.782  0.888 #>  7 qsec   0.419 -0.591 -0.434 #>  8 vs     0.664 -0.811 -0.710 #>  9 am     0.600 -0.523 -0.591 #> 10 gear   0.480 -0.493 -0.556 #> 11 carb  -0.551  0.527  0.395  # Combine above in a single pipeline d %>%   filter(cyl > .7) %>%    select(term, mpg, cyl, disp) #> # A tibble: 3 √ó 4 #>   term     mpg   cyl   disp #>   <chr>  <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 disp  -0.848 0.902 NA     #> 2 hp    -0.776 0.832  0.791 #> 3 wt    -0.868 0.782  0.888 # Compute mean of each column library(purrr) d %>%    select(-term) %>%    map_dbl(~ mean(., na.rm = TRUE)) #>           mpg           cyl          disp            hp          drat  #> -0.1050454113 -0.0925483176 -0.0872737071  0.0006800268 -0.0037165212  #>            wt          qsec            vs            am          gear  #> -0.0828684293 -0.1752247305 -0.1145625942  0.0053087327  0.0484120552  #>          carb  #>  0.0563419513

title: Using corrr
text: section suggests, corrr API designed data pipelines mind (e.g., use %>% magrittr package). correlate(), primary corrr functions take cor_df first argument, return cor_df tbl (output like plot). functions serve one three purposes: Internal changes (cor_df ): shave() upper lower triangle (set NA). rearrange() columns rows based correlation strengths. Reshape structure (tbl cor_df ): focus() select columns rows. stretch() long format. Output/visualizations (console/plot ): fashion() correlations pretty printing. rplot() shape correlation. network_plot() point variable, joined paths correlations. combing functions data pipelines, ‚Äôs possible easily explore correlations. example, lets focus correlations mpg cyl others: maybe want focus variables (mirrored rows ) print correlations without upper triangle fashioned look nice: Alternatively, can visualize correlations (let‚Äôs clear lower triangle change):  Perhaps ‚Äôd like rearrange correlations plot becomes easier interpret. case, can add rearrange() pipeline shaving one triangles (‚Äôll take correlation sign account absolute = FALSE).
code: d %>% focus(mpg, cyl) #> # A tibble: 9 √ó 3 #>   term     mpg    cyl #>   <chr>  <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 disp  -0.848  0.902 #> 2 hp    -0.776  0.832 #> 3 drat   0.681 -0.700 #> 4 wt    -0.868  0.782 #> 5 qsec   0.419 -0.591 #> 6 vs     0.664 -0.811 #> 7 am     0.600 -0.523 #> 8 gear   0.480 -0.493 #> 9 carb  -0.551  0.527 d %>%   focus(mpg:drat, mirror = TRUE) %>%  # Focus only on mpg:drat   shave() %>% # Remove the upper triangle   fashion()   # Print in nice format  #>   term  mpg  cyl disp   hp drat #> 1  mpg                          #> 2  cyl -.85                     #> 3 disp -.85  .90                #> 4   hp -.78  .83  .79           #> 5 drat  .68 -.70 -.71 -.45 d %>%   focus(mpg:drat, mirror = TRUE) %>%   shave(upper = FALSE) %>%   rplot()     # Plot d %>%   focus(mpg:drat, mirror = TRUE) %>%   rearrange(absolute = FALSE) %>%    shave() %>%   rplot()

title: Correlations in R
text: corrr package exploring correlations R. focuses creating working data frames correlations (instead matrices) can easily explored via corrr functions leveraging tools like tidyverse. , along primary corrr functions, represented :  can install: latest released version CRAN latest development version GitHub

title: Correlations in R
text: Using corrr typically starts correlate(), acts like base correlation function cor(). differs defaulting pairwise deletion, returning correlation data frame (cor_df) following structure: tbl additional class, cor_df extra ‚Äúterm‚Äù column Standardized variances (matrix diagonal) set missing values (NA) can ignored.

title: Correlations in R
text: corrr API designed data pipelines mind (e.g., use %>% magrittr package). correlate(), primary corrr functions take cor_df first argument, return cor_df tbl (output like plot). functions serve one three purposes: Internal changes (cor_df ): shave() upper lower triangle (set NA). rearrange() columns rows based correlation strengths. Reshape structure (tbl cor_df ): focus() select columns rows. stretch() long format. Output/visualizations (console/plot ): fashion() correlations pretty printing. rplot() correlations shapes place values. network_plot() correlations network.

title: Correlations in R
text: correlate() function also works database tables. function automatically push calculations correlations database, collect results R, return cor_df object. allows results integrate rest corrr API.

title: Correlations in R
text: NOTE: Previous corrr 0.4.3, first column cor_df dataframe named ‚Äúrowname‚Äù. corrr 0.4.3, name first column changed ‚Äúterm‚Äù. tbl, can use functions data frame packages like dplyr, tidyr, ggplot2: corrr functions work pipelines (cor_df ; cor_df tbl ):
code: library(MASS) library(corrr) set.seed(1)  # Simulate three columns correlating about .7 with each other mu <- rep(0, 3) Sigma <- matrix(.7, nrow = 3, ncol = 3) + diag(3)*.3 seven <- mvrnorm(n = 1000, mu = mu, Sigma = Sigma)  # Simulate three columns correlating about .4 with each other mu <- rep(0, 3) Sigma <- matrix(.4, nrow = 3, ncol = 3) + diag(3)*.6 four <- mvrnorm(n = 1000, mu = mu, Sigma = Sigma)  # Bind together d <- cbind(seven, four) colnames(d) <- paste0("v", 1:ncol(d))  # Insert some missing values d[sample(1:nrow(d), 100, replace = TRUE), 1] <- NA d[sample(1:nrow(d), 200, replace = TRUE), 5] <- NA  # Correlate x <- correlate(d) class(x) #> [1] "cor_df"     "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame" x #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 7 #>   term        v1       v2       v3       v4       v5      v6 #>   <chr>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 v1    NA        0.684    0.716    0.00187 -0.00769 -0.0237 #> 2 v2     0.684   NA        0.702   -0.0248   0.00495 -0.0161 #> 3 v3     0.716    0.702   NA       -0.00171  0.0205  -0.0566 #> 4 v4     0.00187 -0.0248  -0.00171 NA        0.452    0.442  #> 5 v5    -0.00769  0.00495  0.0205   0.452   NA        0.424  #> 6 v6    -0.0237  -0.0161  -0.0566   0.442    0.424   NA library(dplyr)  # Filter rows by correlation size x %>% filter(v1 > .6) #> # A tibble: 2 √ó 7 #>   term     v1     v2     v3       v4      v5      v6 #>   <chr> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 v2    0.684 NA      0.702 -0.0248  0.00495 -0.0161 #> 2 v3    0.716  0.702 NA     -0.00171 0.0205  -0.0566 x <- datasets::mtcars %>%        correlate() %>%    # Create correlation data frame (cor_df)        focus(-cyl, -vs, mirror = TRUE) %>%  # Focus on cor_df without 'cyl' and 'vs'        rearrange() %>%  # rearrange by correlations        shave() # Shave off the upper triangle for a clean result #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs'         fashion(x) #>   term  mpg drat   am gear qsec carb   hp   wt disp #> 1  mpg                                              #> 2 drat  .68                                         #> 3   am  .60  .71                                    #> 4 gear  .48  .70  .79                               #> 5 qsec  .42  .09 -.23 -.21                          #> 6 carb -.55 -.09  .06  .27 -.66                     #> 7   hp -.78 -.45 -.24 -.13 -.71  .75                #> 8   wt -.87 -.71 -.69 -.58 -.17  .43  .66           #> 9 disp -.85 -.71 -.59 -.56 -.43  .39  .79  .89 rplot(x) datasets::airquality %>%    correlate() %>%    network_plot(min_cor = .2) #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs'

title: Create a correlation matrix from a cor_df object ‚Äî autoplot.cor_df
code: # S3 method for cor_df autoplot(   object,   ...,   method = "PCA",   triangular = c("upper", "lower", "full"),   barheight = 20,   low = "#B2182B",   mid = "#F1F1F1",   high = "#2166AC" )

title: Create a correlation matrix from a cor_df object ‚Äî autoplot.cor_df
text: object cor_df object. ... argument ignored. method String specifying arrangement (clustering) method. Clustering achieved via seriate, can consulted complete list clustering methods. Default = "PCA". triangular part correlation matrix shown? Must one "upper", "lower", "full", defaults "upper". barheight single, non-negative number. passed ggplot2::guide_colourbar() determine height guide colorbar. Defaults 20, likely need manual adjustments. low single color. passed ggplot2::scale_fill_gradient2(). color negative correlation. Defaults "#B2182B". mid single color. passed ggplot2::scale_fill_gradient2(). color correlation. Defaults "#F1F1F1". high single color. passed ggplot2::scale_fill_gradient2(). color positive correlation. Defaults "#2166AC".

Correlation Data Frame ‚Äî correlate
text: implementation stats::cor(), returns correlation data frame rather matrix. See details . Additional adjustment include use pairwise deletion default.

title: Correlation Data Frame ‚Äî correlate
code: correlate(   x,   y = NULL,   use = "pairwise.complete.obs",   method = "pearson",   diagonal = NA,   quiet = FALSE )

title: Correlation Data Frame ‚Äî correlate
text: x numeric vector, matrix data frame. y NULL (default) vector, matrix data frame     compatible dimensions x.   default equivalent     y = x (efficient). use optional character string giving     method computing covariances presence     missing values.  must (abbreviation ) one strings     "everything", ".obs", "complete.obs",     "na..complete", "pairwise.complete.obs". method character string indicating correlation     coefficient (covariance) computed.  One     "pearson" (default), "kendall", "spearman":     can abbreviated. diagonal Value (typically numeric NA) set diagonal quiet Set TRUE suppress message method use parameters.

title: Correlation Data Frame ‚Äî correlate
text: correlation data frame cor_df

title: Correlation Data Frame ‚Äî correlate
text: function returns correlation matrix correlation data frame following format: tibble (see tibble) additional class, "cor_df" "term" column Standardized variances (matrix diagonal) set missing values default (NA) can ignored calculations. use argument possible values inherited stats::cor(): "everything": NAs propagate conceptually, .e. resulting value NA whenever one contributing observations NA ".obs": presence missing observations produce error "complete.obs": correlations computed complete observations, error raised complete cases. "na..complete": correlations computed complete observations, returning NA complete cases. "pairwise.complete.obs": correlation pair variables computed using complete pairs particular variables. version 0.4.3, first column cor_df object named "term". previous versions first column named "rowname". ggplot2::autoplot() method quickly visualizing correlation matrix, information see autoplot.cor_df().

title: Correlation Data Frame ‚Äî correlate
code: if (FALSE) { correlate(iris) }  correlate(iris[-5]) #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs' #> # A tibble: 4 √ó 5 #>   term         Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width #>   <chr>               <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 Sepal.Length       NA          -0.118        0.872       0.818 #> 2 Sepal.Width        -0.118      NA           -0.428      -0.366 #> 3 Petal.Length        0.872      -0.428       NA           0.963 #> 4 Petal.Width         0.818      -0.366        0.963      NA      correlate(mtcars) #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs' #> # A tibble: 11 √ó 12 #>    term     mpg    cyl   disp     hp    drat     wt    qsec     vs      am #>    <chr>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> #>  1 mpg   NA     -0.852 -0.848 -0.776  0.681  -0.868  0.419   0.664  0.600  #>  2 cyl   -0.852 NA      0.902  0.832 -0.700   0.782 -0.591  -0.811 -0.523  #>  3 disp  -0.848  0.902 NA      0.791 -0.710   0.888 -0.434  -0.710 -0.591  #>  4 hp    -0.776  0.832  0.791 NA     -0.449   0.659 -0.708  -0.723 -0.243  #>  5 drat   0.681 -0.700 -0.710 -0.449 NA      -0.712  0.0912  0.440  0.713  #>  6 wt    -0.868  0.782  0.888  0.659 -0.712  NA     -0.175  -0.555 -0.692  #>  7 qsec   0.419 -0.591 -0.434 -0.708  0.0912 -0.175 NA       0.745 -0.230  #>  8 vs     0.664 -0.811 -0.710 -0.723  0.440  -0.555  0.745  NA      0.168  #>  9 am     0.600 -0.523 -0.591 -0.243  0.713  -0.692 -0.230   0.168 NA      #> 10 gear   0.480 -0.493 -0.556 -0.126  0.700  -0.583 -0.213   0.206  0.794  #> 11 carb  -0.551  0.527  0.395  0.750 -0.0908  0.428 -0.656  -0.570  0.0575 #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: gear <dbl>, carb <dbl> if (FALSE) {  # Also supports DB backend and collects results into memory  library(sparklyr) sc <- spark_connect(master = "local") mtcars_tbl <- copy_to(sc, mtcars) mtcars_tbl %>%   correlate(use = "pairwise.complete.obs", method = "spearman") spark_disconnect(sc) }

title: Focus on section of a correlation data frame. ‚Äî focus
Focus on section of a correlation data frame. ‚Äî focus
text: x cor_df. See correlate. ... One unquoted expressions separated commas. Variable names can used positions data frame, expressions like `x:y`` can used select range variables. mirror Boolean. Whether mirror selected columns rows . .dots Use focus_ standard evaluations. See select.

title: Focus on section of a correlation data frame. ‚Äî focus
text: tbl , mirror = TRUE, cor_df (see correlate).

title: Focus on section of a correlation data frame. ‚Äî focus
code: library(dplyr) x <- correlate(mtcars) #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs' focus(x, mpg, cyl) # Focus on correlations of mpg and cyl with all other variables #> # A tibble: 9 √ó 3 #>   term     mpg    cyl #>   <chr>  <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 disp  -0.848  0.902 #> 2 hp    -0.776  0.832 #> 3 drat   0.681 -0.700 #> 4 wt    -0.868  0.782 #> 5 qsec   0.419 -0.591 #> 6 vs     0.664 -0.811 #> 7 am     0.600 -0.523 #> 8 gear   0.480 -0.493 #> 9 carb  -0.551  0.527 focus(x, -disp, -mpg, mirror = TRUE) # Remove disp and mpg from columns and rows #> # A tibble: 9 √ó 10 #>   term     cyl     hp    drat     wt    qsec     vs      am   gear    carb #>   <chr>  <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 cyl   NA      0.832 -0.700   0.782 -0.591  -0.811 -0.523  -0.493  0.527  #> 2 hp     0.832 NA     -0.449   0.659 -0.708  -0.723 -0.243  -0.126  0.750  #> 3 drat  -0.700 -0.449 NA      -0.712  0.0912  0.440  0.713   0.700 -0.0908 #> 4 wt     0.782  0.659 -0.712  NA     -0.175  -0.555 -0.692  -0.583  0.428  #> 5 qsec  -0.591 -0.708  0.0912 -0.175 NA       0.745 -0.230  -0.213 -0.656  #> 6 vs    -0.811 -0.723  0.440  -0.555  0.745  NA      0.168   0.206 -0.570  #> 7 am    -0.523 -0.243  0.713  -0.692 -0.230   0.168 NA       0.794  0.0575 #> 8 gear  -0.493 -0.126  0.700  -0.583 -0.213   0.206  0.794  NA      0.274  #> 9 carb   0.527  0.750 -0.0908  0.428 -0.656  -0.570  0.0575  0.274 NA       x <- correlate(iris[-5]) #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs' focus(x, -matches("Sepal")) # Focus on correlations of non-Sepal #> # A tibble: 2 √ó 3 #>   term         Petal.Length Petal.Width #>   <chr>               <dbl>       <dbl> #> 1 Sepal.Length        0.872       0.818 #> 2 Sepal.Width        -0.428      -0.366 # variables with Sepal variables.

what: Conditionally focus correlation data frame ‚Äî focus_if
title: Conditionally focus correlation data frame ‚Äî focus_if
text: Apply predicate function column correlations. Columns evaluate TRUE included call focus.

title: Conditionally focus correlation data frame ‚Äî focus_if
Conditionally focus correlation data frame ‚Äî focus_if
text: x Correlation data frame object coerced one via as_cordf. .predicate predicate function applied columns. columns .predicate returns TRUE included variables focus. ... Additional arguments pass predicate function anonymous. mirror Boolean. Whether mirror selected columns rows .

title: Conditionally focus correlation data frame ‚Äî focus_if
text: tibble , mirror = TRUE, correlation data frame.

title: Conditionally focus correlation data frame ‚Äî focus_if
code: library(dplyr) any_greater_than <- function(x, val) {   mean(abs(x), na.rm = TRUE) > val }  x <- correlate(mtcars) #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs'  x %>% focus_if(any_greater_than, .6) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 6 #>   term     mpg    cyl   disp     hp     wt #>   <chr>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 drat   0.681 -0.700 -0.710 -0.449 -0.712 #> 2 qsec   0.419 -0.591 -0.434 -0.708 -0.175 #> 3 vs     0.664 -0.811 -0.710 -0.723 -0.555 #> 4 am     0.600 -0.523 -0.591 -0.243 -0.692 #> 5 gear   0.480 -0.493 -0.556 -0.126 -0.583 #> 6 carb  -0.551  0.527  0.395  0.750  0.428 x %>% focus_if(any_greater_than, .6, mirror = TRUE) %>% network_plot()

what: Network plot of a correlation data frame ‚Äî network_plot
title: Network plot of a correlation data frame ‚Äî network_plot
text: Output network plot correlation data frame variables highly correlated appear closer together joined stronger paths. Paths also colored sign (blue positive red negative). proximity points determined using multidimensional clustering.

title: Network plot of a correlation data frame ‚Äî network_plot
code: network_plot(   rdf,   min_cor = 0.3,   legend = c("full", "range", "none"),   colours = c("indianred2", "white", "skyblue1"),   repel = TRUE,   curved = TRUE,   colors )

title: Network plot of a correlation data frame ‚Äî network_plot
text: rdf Correlation data frame (see correlate) object can coerced one (see as_cordf). min_cor Number 0 1 indicating minimum value correlations (absolute terms) plot. legend colors legend correlation values displayed? options "full" (default) -1 1 legend, "range" range correlation values rdf legend, "none" colors -1 1 legend displayed. colours, colors Vector colors use n-color gradient. repel variable labels repel ? TRUE, text added via geom_text_repel instead geom_text curved paths curved? TRUE, paths added via geom_curve; FALSE, via geom_segment

title: Network plot of a correlation data frame ‚Äî network_plot
code: x <- correlate(mtcars) #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs' network_plot(x)  network_plot(x, min_cor = .1)  network_plot(x, min_cor = .6)  network_plot(x, min_cor = .2, colors = c("red", "green"), legend = "full")  network_plot(x, min_cor = .2, colors = c("red", "green"), legend = "range")

title: Number of pairwise complete cases. ‚Äî pair_n

title: Number of pairwise complete cases. ‚Äî pair_n

what: Re-arrange a correlation data frame ‚Äî rearrange

title: Re-arrange a correlation data frame ‚Äî rearrange
Re-arrange a correlation data frame ‚Äî rearrange
text: x cor_df. See correlate. method String specifying arrangement (clustering) method. Clustering achieved via seriate, can consulted complete list clustering methods. Default = "PCA". absolute Boolean whether absolute values correlations used clustering.

title: Re-arrange a correlation data frame ‚Äî rearrange
text: cor_df. See correlate.

title: Re-arrange a correlation data frame ‚Äî rearrange

title: Creates a data frame from a stretched correlation table ‚Äî retract
Creates a data frame from a stretched correlation table ‚Äî retract
text: .data data.frame tibble containing least three variables: x, y value x name column use .data x y name column use .data y val name column use .data use value

title: Creates a data frame from a stretched correlation table ‚Äî retract

what: Plot a correlation data frame. ‚Äî rplot
title: Plot a correlation data frame. ‚Äî rplot
text: Plot correlation data frame using ggplot2.

title: Plot a correlation data frame. ‚Äî rplot
code: rplot(   rdf,   legend = TRUE,   shape = 16,   colours = c("indianred2", "white", "skyblue1"),   print_cor = FALSE,   colors,   .order = c("default", "alphabet") )

title: Plot a correlation data frame. ‚Äî rplot
text: rdf Correlation data frame (see correlate) object can coerced one (see as_cordf). legend Boolean indicating whether legend mapping colors correlations displayed. shape geom_point aesthetic. colours, colors Vector colors use n-color gradient. print_cor Boolean indicating whether correlations printed shapes. .order Either "default", meaning x y variables keep order columns x, "alphabet", meaning variables alphabetized.

title: Plot a correlation data frame. ‚Äî rplot
text: Plots correlation data frame

title: Plot a correlation data frame. ‚Äî rplot
text: value correlation data frame represented one point/circle output plot. size point corresponds absolute value correlation (via size aesthetic). color point corresponds signed value correlation (via color aesthetic).

title: Plot a correlation data frame. ‚Äî rplot
code: x <- correlate(mtcars) #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs' rplot(x)   # Common use is following rearrange and shave x <- rearrange(x, absolute = FALSE) x <- shave(x) rplot(x)  rplot(x, print_cor = TRUE)  rplot(x, shape = 20, colors = c("red", "green"), legend = TRUE)

title: Shave off upper/lower triangle. ‚Äî shave
text: Convert upper lower triangle correlation data frame (cor_df) missing values.

title: Shave off upper/lower triangle. ‚Äî shave
Shave off upper/lower triangle. ‚Äî shave
text: x cor_df. See correlate. upper Boolean. TRUE, set upper triangle NA; lower triangle FALSE.

title: Shave off upper/lower triangle. ‚Äî shave
text: cor_df. See correlate.

title: Shave off upper/lower triangle. ‚Äî shave
code: x <- correlate(mtcars) #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs' shave(x) # Default; shave upper triangle #> # A tibble: 11 √ó 12 #>    term     mpg    cyl   disp     hp    drat     wt   qsec     vs      am #>    <chr>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> #>  1 mpg   NA     NA     NA     NA     NA      NA     NA     NA     NA      #>  2 cyl   -0.852 NA     NA     NA     NA      NA     NA     NA     NA      #>  3 disp  -0.848  0.902 NA     NA     NA      NA     NA     NA     NA      #>  4 hp    -0.776  0.832  0.791 NA     NA      NA     NA     NA     NA      #>  5 drat   0.681 -0.700 -0.710 -0.449 NA      NA     NA     NA     NA      #>  6 wt    -0.868  0.782  0.888  0.659 -0.712  NA     NA     NA     NA      #>  7 qsec   0.419 -0.591 -0.434 -0.708  0.0912 -0.175 NA     NA     NA      #>  8 vs     0.664 -0.811 -0.710 -0.723  0.440  -0.555  0.745 NA     NA      #>  9 am     0.600 -0.523 -0.591 -0.243  0.713  -0.692 -0.230  0.168 NA      #> 10 gear   0.480 -0.493 -0.556 -0.126  0.700  -0.583 -0.213  0.206  0.794  #> 11 carb  -0.551  0.527  0.395  0.750 -0.0908  0.428 -0.656 -0.570  0.0575 #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: gear <dbl>, carb <dbl> shave(x, upper = FALSE) # shave lower triangle #> # A tibble: 11 √ó 12 #>    term    mpg    cyl   disp     hp   drat     wt    qsec     vs     am #>    <chr> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #>  1 mpg      NA -0.852 -0.848 -0.776  0.681 -0.868  0.419   0.664  0.600 #>  2 cyl      NA NA      0.902  0.832 -0.700  0.782 -0.591  -0.811 -0.523 #>  3 disp     NA NA     NA      0.791 -0.710  0.888 -0.434  -0.710 -0.591 #>  4 hp       NA NA     NA     NA     -0.449  0.659 -0.708  -0.723 -0.243 #>  5 drat     NA NA     NA     NA     NA     -0.712  0.0912  0.440  0.713 #>  6 wt       NA NA     NA     NA     NA     NA     -0.175  -0.555 -0.692 #>  7 qsec     NA NA     NA     NA     NA     NA     NA       0.745 -0.230 #>  8 vs       NA NA     NA     NA     NA     NA     NA      NA      0.168 #>  9 am       NA NA     NA     NA     NA     NA     NA      NA     NA     #> 10 gear     NA NA     NA     NA     NA     NA     NA      NA     NA     #> 11 carb     NA NA     NA     NA     NA     NA     NA      NA     NA     #> # ‚Ñπ 2 more variables: gear <dbl>, carb <dbl>

what: Stretch correlation data frame into long format. ‚Äî stretch
title: Stretch correlation data frame into long format. ‚Äî stretch
text: stretch specified implementation tidyr::gather() applied correlation data frame. gather columns long-format data frame. term column handled automatically.

title: Stretch correlation data frame into long format. ‚Äî stretch
Stretch correlation data frame into long format. ‚Äî stretch
text: x cor_df. See correlate. na.rm Boolean. Whether rows NA correlation (originally matrix diagonal) dropped? automatically set TRUE mirror FALSE. remove.dups Removes duplicate entries, without removing NAs

title: Stretch correlation data frame into long format. ‚Äî stretch
text: tbl three columns (x y variables, correlation)

title: Stretch correlation data frame into long format. ‚Äî stretch
code: x <- correlate(mtcars) #> Correlation computed with #> ‚Ä¢ Method: 'pearson' #> ‚Ä¢ Missing treated using: 'pairwise.complete.obs' stretch(x) # Convert all to long format #> # A tibble: 121 √ó 3 #>    x     y          r #>    <chr> <chr>  <dbl> #>  1 mpg   mpg   NA     #>  2 mpg   cyl   -0.852 #>  3 mpg   disp  -0.848 #>  4 mpg   hp    -0.776 #>  5 mpg   drat   0.681 #>  6 mpg   wt    -0.868 #>  7 mpg   qsec   0.419 #>  8 mpg   vs     0.664 #>  9 mpg   am     0.600 #> 10 mpg   gear   0.480 #> # ‚Ñπ 111 more rows stretch(x, na.rm = TRUE) # omit NAs (diagonal in this case) #> # A tibble: 110 √ó 3 #>    x     y          r #>    <chr> <chr>  <dbl> #>  1 mpg   cyl   -0.852 #>  2 mpg   disp  -0.848 #>  3 mpg   hp    -0.776 #>  4 mpg   drat   0.681 #>  5 mpg   wt    -0.868 #>  6 mpg   qsec   0.419 #>  7 mpg   vs     0.664 #>  8 mpg   am     0.600 #>  9 mpg   gear   0.480 #> 10 mpg   carb  -0.551 #> # ‚Ñπ 100 more rows  x <- shave(x) # use shave to set upper triangle to NA and then... stretch(x, na.rm = TRUE) # omit all NAs, therefore keeping each #> # A tibble: 55 √ó 3 #>    x     y          r #>    <chr> <chr>  <dbl> #>  1 mpg   cyl   -0.852 #>  2 mpg   disp  -0.848 #>  3 mpg   hp    -0.776 #>  4 mpg   drat   0.681 #>  5 mpg   wt    -0.868 #>  6 mpg   qsec   0.419 #>  7 mpg   vs     0.664 #>  8 mpg   am     0.600 #>  9 mpg   gear   0.480 #> 10 mpg   carb  -0.551 #> # ‚Ñπ 45 more rows # correlation only once.

title: corrr 0.4.4
text: CRAN release: 2022-08-16 Make colpair_map() robust input column names, exception ‚Äú.data‚Äù ‚Äú.env‚Äù (@jameslairdsmith, #131). correlate() now removes non-numeric columns data frame inputs (@thisisdaryn, #139). autoplot.cor_df() method added quick generation correlation chart. network_plot() now allows user option map color range range correlations input rdf (@thisisdaryn, #158).

title: corrr 0.4.3
text: CRAN release: 2020-11-24 Fix EOL issues class attribute (@krlmlr, #93 #90) Handle correlation exactly zero 1 network_plot() (@s-scherrer, #89) Add .order argument rplot() options ‚Äúdefault‚Äù ‚Äúalphabet‚Äù plus improved documentation (@mattwarkentin, #99 @thisisdaryn, #114) Make network_plot() robust, example highly correlated data (@thisisdaryn, #107) New colpair_map() allows column comparisons using values returned arbitrary function (@jameslairdsmith, #94). correlate() now works single-column data.frames numeric vectors (@antoine-sachet, #122). Note diagonal argument ignored 2 cases. network_plot() now works cor_df objects 1 2 columns (@antoine-sachet, #122) first column cor_df object now named ‚Äúterm‚Äù. Previously named ‚Äúrowname‚Äù (@thisisdaryn, #117).

title: corrr 0.4.2
text: CRAN release: 2020-03-22 Updates work tibble 3.0.0 dplyr 1.0.0

title: corrr 0.4.1
text: CRAN release: 2020-02-10 Updates maintainer

title: corrr 0.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2019-07-12 Adds remove.dups argument stretch(). removes duplicates removing NAs (#57) Adds dice() function, wraps focus(x,..., mirror = TRUE) (#64) Adds retract() function, opposite stretch() (#65) Improves correlate() database backed tables Fixes compatibility issues dplyr

title: corrr 0.3.2
text: CRAN release: 2019-04-20 Improves support tbl_sql() objects Switches correlation calculation tbl_spark() tables sparklyr::ml_corr() Adds package level doc (@jsta, #66) Fixes typo error message (@jsta) Removes Database vignette. Plan re-add later (#76) Minor updates Using corrr vignette

title: corrr 0.3.1
text: CRAN release: 2019-03-06 Fixes test CRAN issues removing Ops.cor_df(). Designates Edgar Ruiz new package maintainer

title: corrr 0.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2018-07-31

title: corrr 0.3.0
text: diagonal argument as_matrix as_matrix.cor_df now optional argument rather set 1 default #52

title: corrr 0.3.0
text: as_cordf coerce lists matrices correlation data frames possible. focus_if enables conditional variable selection.

title: corrr 0.3.0
text: Can use arithmetic operators (e.g., + -) correlation data frames. Plotting functions (rplot network_plot) attempt coerce objects correlation data frame (via as_cordf) needed, making possible directly use functions square-matrix-like objects. repel option added network_plot (default = TRUE). curved option added network_plot (default = TRUE). correlate() now prints message method use parameters. Can silenced quiet = TRUE. correlate() now supports data frame SQL back-end (tbl_sql)

title: corrr 0.3.0
text: legend = TRUE (now default setting), rplot network_plot generate single, unlabeled legend referring size correlations.

title: corrr 0.3.0
text: correlate() now S3 method can adapt x‚Äôs object type. development version, ggplot v2.2.0 released. Many changes plotting functions made handle new features updated version ggplot2. Improvements package folder structure

title: corrr 0.2.1
text: CRAN release: 2016-10-10

title: corrr 0.2.1
text: Can keep leading zeros using fashion() new argument leading_zeros = TRUE. legend display legend mapping correlations size colour. colours (colors) change colours plot.

title: corrr 0.2.1
text: network_plot() longer plots wrong colours positive correlations included. Colour scheme network_plot() changed match rplot(). bug fixes.

title: corrr 0.2.0
text: CRAN release: 2016-08-11

title: corrr 0.2.0
text: network_plot() correlations. focus_() standard evaluation version focus().

title: corrr 0.2.0
text: fashion() now attempt work object (just cor_df), making useful printing data frame, matrix, vector, etc. print_cor argument added rplot() overlay correlations text.

title: corrr 0.2.0
text: na_omit argument stretch() changed na.rm match gather_(). Bug fixes. Improvements.

title: corrr 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2016-07-08 First corrr release!
